content.intro:
The legendary capital of Tunisia is located on the country's northern coast. The beautiful, broad Parisian-style boulevards recall the city's former self. The thriving heart of the country, Tunis is charged with history while confronting modernity, a combination that has created a rich and varied culture of past, present, and future.

Political and economic capital of the country and home to numerous UNESCO World Heritage sites, Tunis is a moving and fascinating city. With a vibrant downtown, where important scientific and cultural conferences are often held, Tunis is considered a showcase of North African development. The mild Mediterranean climate, broad white sand beaches and blue waters attract many to this welcoming city and its nearby sites.

You can start your exploration at the centre of one of the most beautiful medinas in the country, dating back to the late 7th century. One feels the authenticity of the multitude of architectural treasures here, from stately homes and palaces to mosques and even zaouias, Muslim religious buildings. This trip back in time will let you meander among the wonders of the country. Find your way through the maze of souks, barter with craftsmen for some souvenirs, or head to the central market, where aromas and colours provide you with an experience you won't soon forget. Continue your odyssey to the new city where you'll find Haussmannian architecture, as on the famous Avenue Habib Bourguiba, named after the father of Tunisian independence. You can also discover small streets lined with Art Deco buildings. A bit further afield, visit the neighbourhood of La Goulette, Tunisia's main port, about ten kilometres from the city centre.

The ruins of mythical Carthage are also a must during your stay. You will have the privilege of admiring the vestiges of the Roman and Byzantine period here. Continue on your way to the melodious Sidi Bou Saïd, a small village of infinite charm above the Gulf of Tunis with amazing panoramic views of the Mediterranean. With the first rays of sun in the morning, you will be amazed by the white walls of the pretty houses, which contrast with the intense deep blue of the doors and shutters. The faint scent of pink bougainvillea adds to this spectacle, as if it were needed, a touch of sweetness. Finally, you can make a detour to La Marsa, where you'll see one of the most charming landscapes of the area and take in a chic, relaxed atmosphere.

content.title: Gallery Gorgi, expression of Tunisian contemporary art

introduction.small: In the Sidi Bou Saïd suburb of Tunis, this space sheds a light on new art trends and the national contemporary scene.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gallery Gorgi, expression of Tunisian contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
Pioneer of contemporary art display and always on the lookout for upcoming Tunisian talents, Gallery A. Gorgi delights art lovers with each event. It used to be less specialised, but art direction was changed in 2010 under the impulse of curator Aïcha Gorgi. In that respect, the daughter of Abdelaziz Gorgi, painter and leading figure in 20th-century Tunisia, has chosen to concentrate exclusively on today's creation.
The gallery has since become a major player in the country. Twice a year, it presents a new thematic exhibition, directly linked to current issues, always innovative and judicious: take on life and the world by plastic artists, selection of works by several contemporary drawing artists… A. Gorgi is more than ever the current nursery for upcoming talents.

Galerie A. Gorgi
3, rue Sidi El Ghemrini
Sidi Bou Saïd 2026

+216 55 665 500

www.facebook.com/agorgi/ ﻿

content.title: La Villa Bleue, in the heart of Sidi Bou Saïd

introduction.small: Twenty kilometres north of Tunis, La Villa Bleue Hotel is a haven of peace in a gorgeous setting: picturesque village and views of the Gulf de Tunis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Villa Bleue, in the heart of Sidi Bou Saïd

paragraphs.text:
In the heights of Sidi Bou Saïd, La Villa Bleue is a great viewpoint overlooking the Gulf of Tunis, port and city. The village is full of Tunisian charm, with white and blue houses built according to traditional architecture.

La Villa Bleue is located in a 1991 home where typical Arabo-Andalousian style prevails. Each of the 13 rooms and suites is enhanced with rich materials such as marble and ceramic, and blue and grey colours that will bring a certain serenity.
Most balconies overlook the sea, where you can enjoy having a tea at the end of the day. Also choose from one of the two swimming pools – heated or unheated – to do a few improvised laps, or head to the spa or hammam for a pleasant moment of relaxation.
For dinner, the panoramic restaurant, Le Lounge, will satisfy your taste buds. On the menu, Mediterranean dishes concocted with local products under the guidance of two-Michelin star chef Jean-François Issautier.

La Villa Bleue
68, rue Kennedy
2026 Sidi Bou Saïd

+216 71 742 000

www.lavillableuesidibousaid.com

Rooms: from 180 EUR

content.title: The old port of Bizerte, northwest of Tunis

introduction.small: Multi-coloured boats in a very calm place… Escape the bustle of Tunis and take refuge in warm Bizerte.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The old port of Bizerte, northwest of Tunis

paragraphs.text: From Tunis, it will take only an hour to drive to Bizerte, a small city that has kept all of its Tunisian charm, where it's nice to take a walk on a sunny day, cooled off by the sea breeze. Start at the lovely fishing port, where boats of all colours collide to the gentle rhythm of the ripples in the water. Houses with white facades and blue doors face century-old walls that surround the Kasbah on the other side of the canal. From there, the view of the city is incredible. Below, aisles of the souk are bustling with the cries of the merchants. Further ahead lies the Fort d'Espagne, or Spanish Fort, transformed into what is now an outdoor theatre that hosts many performances, including the International Festival of Bizerte. From this magical viewpoint, all the wonders of the city unfold before you.

content.title: Dar Saïd Hotel, in a former town house

introduction.small: A subtle mix of Tunisian and European decor, in classic and contemporary styles, for a lovely stay overlooking the waters of the Mediterranean.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar Saïd Hotel, in a former town house

paragraphs.text:
Located on the cliffs of the village of Sidi Bou Saïd, 15 minutes from the airport and the centre of Tunis, the Dar Saïd hotel overlooks the vastness of the Mediterranean. Built in the mid-19th century, this boutique hotel has retained the soul of an old mansion. Make yourself at home in one of the 24 guest rooms, all with elements of oriental architecture, some with columns, some with blue tiles, and all tastefully decorated.

The Moorish architecture of the hotel's layout, composed of fountains, patios, wrought iron, and zellige tile work, immerses you in a memorable atmosphere. It is in absolute tranquillity that the Dar Saïd, in a lush setting awash in bougainvillea and jasmine, cultivates its art de vivre, sharing all this with its passing guests.

Make yourself comfortable on one of the garden terraces, which border the sparkling pool and offer striking views of the majestic Gulf of Tunis. Opposite the hotel, the restaurant Dar Zarrouk invites you for a meal that blends Mediterranean and Tunisian cuisine in a stunning setting with a view of the marina and the bay.

Dar Saïd Hotel
Rue Toumi
Sidi Bou Saïd 2026

+216 (0)71 729 666

www.darsaid.com.tn

Rooms: from 452 TND

content.title: Les Berges du Lac Concorde: a grand hotel

introduction.small: The prestige of a refined and authentic hotel with a tremendous view.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Berges du Lac Concorde: a grand hotel

paragraphs.text:
This large luxury hotel offers a unique setting with a panoramic view of the majestic Lake Tunis near the Tunis-Carthage airport, between the Medina of Tunis, Sidi Bou Saïd, and the archaeological sites of Carthage.

With a perfect location in the heart of the capital's business district, the hotel has a decor that combines contemporary and classic touches: glossy marble, carved stone, Italian panelling, and deep sofas. Its 129 rooms are comfortable, modern, and functional, and will meet the highest expectations.

Enjoy a swim in the indoor pool, a Nuxe massage, or a moment of wellness in the steam room or sauna. Les Berges du Lac Concorde, renowned for its culinary tradition, will delight your taste buds with subtle delicacies in one of several restaurants. The bar and lounge areas also offer a place for a drink or a gourmet snack.

Les Berges du Lac Concorde
Rue du Lac Turkana
Tunis 1053

+216 (0)71 961 951

www.concorde-tunisia.com

Rooms: from 480 TND

content.title: Dar Sabri: the enchanting charm of the Orient

introduction.small: A cheerful oasis two steps from the beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar Sabri: the enchanting charm of the Orient

paragraphs.text:
Located south of Tunis along the beautiful coast of the Gulf of Hammamet, Dar Sabri welcomes you in luxurious, modern, and contemporary settings for a prestigious stay. In the midst of beautiful gardens, the hotel has an exceptional location near one of the most beautiful beaches of the Tunisian coast.

Decorated with a successfully updated local style, the whitewashed walls welcome you in warm riads and in four decorated suites, all set around a central patio with a streaming fountain.

After basking on the deck and appreciating the warm Mediterranean climate around the sparkling pool, enjoy the restaurant, which serves Tunisian specialities, such as tagines and couscous, in the pure oriental tradition. Remember to relax in the steam room and make the most of their spa treatments.

Dar Sabri
Avenue Farhat Hached, impasse 7
Nabeul 8000

+216 (0)72 272 877

www.dar-sabri.com

Rooms: from 215 TND

content.title: Hammamet: a beach town

introduction.small: South of Cape Bon, Hammamet has become the top tourist destination of Tunisia, in part thanks to the efforts, in the 1930s, of the Romanian-born millionaire Georges Sebastien.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hammamet: a beach town

paragraphs.text:
Just 80 kilometres from Tunis, Hammamet is a resort town that is extremely popular with international tourists and Tunisians alike. With its mild climate and never-ending beaches, the southern part of Cape Bon has continually renewed its popularity.

A former fishing village, the town is one of the two other major tourist destinations in the country, along with Djerba. While the beaches are the main reason, the heart of the medina, surrounded by ramparts, remains a good place for walks, thanks to its sparkling white houses with their colourful doors.

Many narrow streets lead you to the souk and the kasbah, built on an ancient fort. Once at the top, enjoy the magnificent panoramic view of the beaches and orchards. You will discover a warm and relaxed, vibrant city, full of charm. Also visit the villa of Georges Sebastian, a wealthy Romanian-born gentleman who brought many stars to his winter home, which was featured in American and Parisian Vogue in the 1930s.

Hammamet Tourism Office
Avenue de la république
Hammamet 8050

+216 72 280 423

content.title: L'Astragale: for exceptional service and excellent French cuisine

introduction.small: A delicious French restaurant in a residential area of the Tunisian capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Astragale: for exceptional service and excellent French cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Conveniently located in the centre of the Belvedere district, behind a beautiful green garden with water running into a fountain, L'Astragale offers traditional French cuisine to its guests.

With its classic-chic interior, friendly service, and a menu that changes with the seasons, L'Astragale will charm you. You can start your meal with a delicate grouper carpaccio, marinated with pink peppercorns, followed by a delicious duck à l'orange or rabbit cooked with Dijon mustard, all accompanied by one of the select wines available. End your meal with a medley of desserts.

The quality cuisine has made the restaurant's name internationally, and its reasonable prices attract a regular clientele.

L'Astragale

content.title: The Archaeological Site of Carthage: a powerful visit

introduction.small: You can stroll among the ruins of time at the must-see archaeological site of Carthage, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and an easy train ride from Tunis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Archaeological Site of Carthage: a powerful visit

paragraphs.text:
Located about 20 kilometres from the centre of Tunis, the site of Carthage, once forgotten, is now famous around the world. With its glorious but tormented past, the city, founded by the Phoenician Princess Elissa almost 3,000 years ago, reveals the traces of its history to visitors, reminding us that, here, the fate of the Mediterranean was played out.

Meaning ‘new town' in Phoenician, Carthage became, thanks to its position in the Gulf of Tunis, the centre of a major trading empire covering the whole Mediterranean basin. During the Punic Wars, the city occupied territories belonging to Rome, which finally destroyed it in 146 BC. The Romans later built a second Carthage on the ruins of the first in the first century AD.

Among the ruins, do not miss the Odeon (a small theatre-like space used for music), the larger theatre, and the Antonine Baths. Stroll among the ruins and the marble rubble, lined with eucalyptus, pepper trees, bougainvillea, and mimosa, and appreciate the amazing view over the sea.

content.title: The Great Mosque of Kairouan: a prestigious mosque with a view

introduction.small: Considered one of the most beautiful mosques in the country, this is a splendid example of Islamic architecture, classified as a UNESCO World Heritage site, in the heart of a stunning city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Great Mosque of Kairouan: a prestigious mosque with a view

paragraphs.text:
Located 150 kilometres due south from Tunis, the Mosque of Kairouan is one of the must-see sites of any trip to northern Tunisia. Restored starting in 1962, the mosque is considered one of the most prestigious religious monuments in the country.

Built by Uqba ibn Nafi, an Arab general, around 680 AD (it is also called the Mosque of Uqba), this is the first mosque in the Islamic West. The Mosque has Aghlabid architecture and appears as a fortress on a hill.

You can admire its immense courtyard in white marble, framed with a gallery of columns in blue granite that come from archaeological sites, and a sundial that shows the faithful the time for prayer. A jewel not to be missed, the Great Mosque is unique due to its age, authenticity, singular history, and the quality of its architecture.

Great Mosque
Rue de la Kasbah
3100 Kairouan

www.patrimoinedetunisie.com.tn/fr/monuments/mosquee_kairouan.php

content.title: La Marsa: traditional elegance

introduction.small: This charming seaside neighbourhood is reachable by the TGM train.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Marsa: traditional elegance

paragraphs.text:
Located 18 kilometres north-east of Tunis, many consider La Marsa the most welcoming of the northern Tunis suburbs. Visitors will find clear, green water on the shore in a warm, family-friendly atmosphere with multiple terraces in the sun.

La Marsa retains its character from yesteryear when it was a summer residence for high-ranking officials of the Ottoman empire. You can admire many houses that have retained an epochal style, the restored synagogue, or the Abdalliya Palace right near the port. Perhaps you can grab a meal at the Factory restaurant, in the Koubet El Haoua building on stilts right at the entry to the beach.

In the late afternoon, take time to unwind with a drink at the Saf Saf Café, and enjoy the sunset before taking in the evening entertainment that will brighten up your night.

content.title: The Medina of Tunis: a pure joy

introduction.small: An authentic site, full of culture, for a unique promenade in an unforgettable medina.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Medina of Tunis: a pure joy

paragraphs.text:
A UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1979, the Tunis medina, the historic centre of Tunis is among the most important treasures of the Islamic world. Built in the 7th century around the Zaituna Mosque, the old town is home to no less than 670 monuments including palaces, mansions, mosques, zaouias, madrasahs, and even mausoleums.

The area offers an impressive selection of elements of Muslim urbanism with fabulous ruins and typical decoration. With its many rustic buildings, some in disrepair, and its narrow and bustling streets, the medina is full of exceptional areas to explore. Enter through the main gate, Bab el Bahr or the ‘Gate of the Sea', which symbolizes the end of the new city and the beginning of the medina.

Lose yourself in its twists and turns before reaching the many souks: the perfumers, fez manufacturers, fabric and cotton vendors, goldsmiths, saddlers, blacksmiths, and dyers. Barter away for the treasures you'd like to take home!

+216 71 904 154

www.culture.alecso.org/medinatunis

content.title: The Bardo National Museum: a modern museum, for antiquities

introduction.small: This exceptional museum has imposed itself as a cultural point of reference thanks to its impressive collections.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bardo National Museum: a modern museum, for antiquities

paragraphs.text:
Just outside the centre of Tunis, the Bardo Museum is the oldest and largest Tunisian museum, located in one of the pavilions of a bey palace dating from the 19th century that still displays the splendour of a princely residence. The museum offers visitors an important and unique collection of objects from excavations at archaeological sites from different areas in the country, such as Sousse, Carthage, and Dougga.

Objects are spread out among 50 rooms and galleries, tracing the history of Tunisia chronologically, from ancient times to the present day. The Bardo is the second most important museum on the African continent, after Cairo's, and has built its reputation through a collection of mosaics considered one of the most beautiful and diverse in the world.

The Islamic department has an elegant collection of ceramics from North Africa and Asia Minor. Other rooms contain objects that belonged to the ruling family; Israelite objects are also on view.

The Bardo National Museum
Route Nationale, 7
Tunis

+216 (0)71 513 650

www.bardomuseum.tn

content.title: Le Light Bar at Villa Didon: for a festive atmosphere

introduction.small: An elegant and trendy place, with a view over the immense Bay of Tunis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Light Bar at Villa Didon: for a festive atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
Located on the heights of Carthage, the Villa Didon Hotel combines a 19th century style and the clean lines of contemporary architecture. With its magnificent interior done in marble and surrounded by hanging gardens, it is one of the highlights of the Tunis night.

Head to the Light Bar here, a chic and stylish haven with a festive atmosphere, which will welcome you to one of its large outdoor terraces overlooking the Bay of Tunis and the wonderful Punic ports. This is the place to be, dedicated to an exclusive and trendy clientele. Lit by delicate blue neon lights, it offers you an evening out (until late, if you wish), around the many flavours of original mixed cocktails. You can also choose from an extensive menu of exceptional local or foreign wines, which you can accompany with gourmet delights.

If you are up for some music, a DJ will be spinning lounge music here on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays. Guests can also enjoy a unique selection of teas and pastries in the afternoons.

Le Light Bar at Villa Didon
Rue Mendès-France
Carthage Byrsa
Tunis 2016

+216 31 323 000

www.villadidoncarthage.com

Menu: around 60 TND

content.title: Dar El Haddad: one of the medina's finest palaces

introduction.small: One of the oldest and most refined of the palaces of Tunis, Dar El Haddad is a gem to visit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar El Haddad: one of the medina's finest palaces

paragraphs.text:
Since the 18th-century, this building has borne the name of Saïd el-Haddad, a wealthy fez maker who belonged to one of the most important Andalusian families to arrive in Tunisia after the fall of Granada. The family quickly made its fortune and acquired this exceptional palace, today classified as a historic monument and restored by the national archaeological services.

Before the entry, on both sides of the impasse, are stables and other palace annexes. Two vestibules with side benches lead to the courtyard, which is surrounded by columns in porticoes. The architectural splendour of the residence will dazzle you, from the painted wood ceilings to the magnificence of the galleries and rooms.

With an original overall layout and a huge variety of decorative elements, this building is a sumptuous blend of Ottoman and Andalusian influences and it is also one of the Tunis medina's most remarkable buildings.

Dar El Haddad
Rue du château
Tunis

+216 (0)71 341 077

content.title: Zitouna Mosque : an impressive site in the medina

introduction.small: An iconic presence in the life of Tunisians, this sumptuous mosque is the most ancient and vast in all of Tunis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zitouna Mosque : an impressive site in the medina

paragraphs.text:
This mosque in the Medina of Tunis, the Zitouna Mosque, or ‘Mosque of the Olive Tree' was founded in the late 7th century. Legend has it that the spot on which the mosque is located was a place of prayer where an ancient olive tree (zitouna) was also found. It is the oldest and largest mosque in the city.

Covering approximately 5,000 square metres, the mosque has nine entries and 184 majestic ancient columns taken from the site of Carthage. The long courtyard is trapezoidal, repeating elements from the mosques of Cordoba and Kairouan.

At the entrance to the prayer hall, the dome of the narthex, with a beautiful gallery, has columns and ancient capitals at its base. The main place of worship in the city, residents celebrate many ceremonies here, often in the presence of high religious authorities.

Zitouna Mosque
Rue Jamaa Ezzitouna
Tunis

+216 (0)71 904 154

www.patrimoinedetunisie.com.tn/fr/monuments/ezzitouna.php

content.title: Villa Didon Hotel: at the heart of an archaeological park

introduction.small: A hotel and spa with a refined design and an exceptional panoramic view.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Didon Hotel: at the heart of an archaeological park

paragraphs.text:
Anchored on the wonderful hill of Carthage, the iconic Villa Didon Hotel welcomes you with its 19th-century style and sleek contemporary interiors. This legendary hotel, both modern and elegant, once brought together poets, aesthetes, and night owls in search of serenity.

With interiors of black-and-white marble and its magnificent hanging gardens, the hotel offers you a stay in one of ten bright suites, each of which has a stunning view over the Bay of Tunis. Relax in the hotel spa, which blends Arab hammams and Roman baths for a moment of comfort.

Enjoy a delicious dinner in the sumptuous restaurant that will allow you to sample the multi-ethnic cuisine in a friendly and refined setting, while offering stunning views of Carthage.

Villa Didon Hotel
Rue Mendès-France
Carthage Byrsa 2016

+216 (0)71 733 433

www.villadidoncarthage.com

Rooms: from 400 TND

content.title: Dar El Jeld: for an exceptional moment

introduction.small: A gastronomic Tunisian restaurant with traditional flavours and a local feel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar El Jeld: for an exceptional moment

paragraphs.text:
The Dar El Jeld signature restaurant, located in a fantastic Tunisian building in the heart of the Medina of Tunis, welcomes its guests in a candlelit, refined atmosphere. With its simple and elegant furniture, whitewashed walls, and carved ceilings, the establishment is in the heart of a shaded courtyard, under ancient arches and alongside beautiful mosaics, making this one of Tunis' most refined settings.

Exceptional service and Tunisian flavours come together to offer a prestigious meal. Guests can enjoy a succulent stuffed lamb shoulder served with rice, almonds, and raisins, or a majestic fish couscous. It is possible for you to accompany your feast with a local wine.

Do not miss the irresistible Tunisian pastries, sparkling with honey. And, afterwards, head to the restaurant boutique, which offers fine quality traditional crafts to take home.

Dar El Jeld
5, rue Dar El Jeld
Tunis 1002

+216 (0)71 560 916

www.dareljeld.com

Menu: around 70 TND

content.title: Lounge Dar Zarrouk: for a glamorous evening on the town

introduction.small: A lounge worth a visit in the hills of Sidi Bou Saïd.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lounge Dar Zarrouk: for a glamorous evening on the town

paragraphs.text:
Nestled in an ancient house in the hills of Sidi Bou Saïd, the Lounge Dar Zarrouk, one of the first lounges to have emerged in the metropolitan area of Tunis, offers a festive atmosphere.

Imbued with the magic and warmth of the village, it offers its guests a pleasant, cosy, and trendy setting, surrounded by lush vegetation. You can relax inside, on the white, red, and black modern seats and sofas, or opt for the intimate outdoor courtyard, under the branches of an ancient tree. Browse through the extensive cocktail menu served until late into the night.

Whether for a drink with friends or for a casual business meeting, the Lounge Dar Zarrouk has a unique atmosphere that is both relaxed and glamorous. All year round, the lounge hosts local elites as well as trendy expatriates. Feel free to dine at Dar Zarrouk where you will discover delicious gourmet Mediterranean cuisine.

Lounge Dar Zarrouk
Rue Hedi-Zarrouk
Sidi Bou Saïd 2026

+216 71 740 591

www.darzarrouk.com/bars/

Menu: around 15 TND

content.title: St. Vincent de Paul Cathedral: an icon of another era

introduction.small: Located in the very centre of Tunis, the St Vincent de Paul Cathedral welcomes visitors, tourists, and worshippers alike.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: St. Vincent de Paul Cathedral: an icon of another era

paragraphs.text:
Dating from 1893, this magnificent cathedral is dedicated to Our Lady and to St. Vincent de Paul, who was captured and sold into slavery in Tunis in the early 17th century. At the intersection of the Avenue Habib Bourguiba and Avenue de France, the sublime cathedral sits majestically on Independence Square.

Considered one of the most important Catholic monuments in the city and built in a beautiful Roman-Byzantine style, this cathedral is as impressive inside as it is outside. Once across the threshold, you will discover the splendour of the recently renovated building.

You will notice both Roman and Eastern-inspired decorations and statues of angels on the facade. Whether you are practising or not, do not hesitate to discover this exceptional monument, which was visited, in 1998, by Pope John Paul II.

St. Vincent de Paul Cathedral
4, rue d'Alger
Tunis 1000

+216 71 338 935

www.cathedraledetunis.org

content.title: Sidi Bou Saïd: a village of light

introduction.small: Numerous poems and songs sing its praises. Rightly so, as Sidi Bou Saïd is a tremendously beautiful village of calm and quiet, on a cliff overlooking the Mediterranean.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sidi Bou Saïd: a village of light

paragraphs.text:
Located about 22 kilometres from Tunis, Sidi Bou Saïd, a charming little village above the bay, is very worth a visit. As of the 19th century, the Tunisian bourgeoisie took hold of this peaceful haven, and, shortly thereafter, luminaries from around the world, such as André Gide and Simone de Beauvoir, followed.

With stunning views over the Mediterranean, you can contemplate the bright white of the houses contrasting with the intensity of the blue doors and shutters. During your walk, revel in the scent of jasmine and flowering bougainvillea.

The magnificence of this landscape brings a touch of melodic calm and gentleness. Also take advantage of the steep streets that lead to magnificent views of the Gulf of Tunis. Relax with a mint tea or dine at any of the choice options that make the most of the views of the bay.

Café des Délices
Impasse de la corniche
2026 Sidi Bou Saïd

+216 71 749 661

www.facebook.com/Sidi-Chabaane-Cafe-Des-Delices-500186716679988/

content.title: Chez Slah: the king of fish

introduction.small: A charming restaurant, frequented by locals, known for its excellent fish.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Slah: the king of fish

paragraphs.text:
Off the beaten track, this inescapable address for Tunisians welcomes you behind an anonymous blue door for a traditional meal made exclusively with fresh fish and seafood.

This hidden treasure with a friendly atmosphere is unpretentious and attracts a local clientele and business travellers who meet for a meal in the cosy dining room. With attentive service and delicious cuisine, the restaurant is often crowded, so book your dinner table in advance.

You may start your gastronomic journey with a plate of seafood featuring squid and cuttlefish, and then continue with grilled fish, such as red mullet, sea bass, or sea bream, before finishing with a gigantic cup of whipped cream and seasonal fruit. You can't go wrong in this good address.

Chez Slah
14, rue Pierre de Coubertin
Tunis 1000

+216 (0)71 258 588

Menu: from 40 TND

content.title: Dar El Medina: both chic and elegant

introduction.small: A timeless voyage into the heart of the famous medina.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar El Medina: both chic and elegant

paragraphs.text:
Located in the centre of the magnificent Medina of Tunis, Dar El Medina welcomes you for an enchanting and majestic stay. Time seems to stand still in this sumptuous hotel, which has a cosy interior and traditional decor: subtle woodwork, carpets, and glowing blue azure tiles.

Only 100 metres from major attractions, this hotel combines luxury and refinement. Settle onto one of the coloured benches in the tearoom or bask on the rooftop terrace to admire the breath-taking panoramic view.

The 12 rooms welcome you with charm, and the helpful and enthusiastic staff will make your stay unforgettable. Stroll a few hours in the souks of Tunis, and lose yourself in the scents of a thousand spices, knowing you are only a few steps away from a good night's rest.

Dar El Medina
64, rue Sidi Ben Arous
Tunis 1006

Tel : +216 (0)71 563 022

www.darelmedina.com

Rooms: from 98 TND

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Tunis
content.introduction: Tunis enjoys a typically Mediterranean climate. Winters are cool and rainy. Summers are usually hot and dry, although sea breezes moderate temperatures somewhat.

airports.description:
The Tunis-Carthage International Airport is located about 8 kilometres (5 miles) northeast of Tunis.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2 (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Tunis and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the N9.
    • A car park with 2,500 spaces is located in proximity to both terminals (TND 2 per hour for the closest, TND 1 per hour for the farthest).
  • By bus
    • Bus 35 operated by the SNT leaves the airport every 40 minutes and terminates at Tunis Marine train station on Avenue Habib Bourguiba in the city centre. The trip takes 15-30 minutes and the fare is TND 0.76 each way.
    • Bus 635 connects the airport with the city centre every 30 minutes, with a travel time of about 30 minutes (around TND 0.45 each way).
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the terminals. The trip to the city centre takes about 20 minutes and costs around TND 8 (a 50% supplement is charged after 9 p.m.).
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, bank, post office and free Internet Access (Wi-Fi) are available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +216 (0)71 754 000
  • Website: www.oaca.nat.tn

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Tunis
transportation.description: Tunis has a good public transport system and is an easy city to get around. In addition to its many bus routes, the city has a modern light rail network covering the entire metropolitan area, including districts on the outskirts.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Tunis, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Tunisia travel guide
information.description:
The ONTT's official website provides a wealth of information on Tunis.

  • Website: www.discovertunisia.com

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home. Tunis counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
Booster doses of diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and polio vaccines are recommended. Depending on the length of your stay and hygiene conditions, the following additional vaccinations are also recommended: typhoid, hepatitis A and B.

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description:
There are few risks of food safety in Tunis. However, it is recommended to:

  • carefully wash produce before eating
  • avoid eating raw food

information.title: Water
information.description: Although tap water is usually safe to drink in Tunis, it is recommended to drink only bottled water during your stay.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Arabic phrases that will make your stay in Tunis a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Sabah al-khair
What time is it ?: Kam el sa'ah?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Tunis
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Tunis each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: Third month of the Hijri calendar: Mawlid (Birth of the Prophet, national)
events.description: This festival celebrated on the twelfth day of Rabi'al-Awwal commemorates the birth of the Prophet Muhammad and is one of the most important days on the Hijri calendar. Tunisian Muslims use this opportunity to recall the values advocated by the Prophet. It is also a day when families gather to share a traditional meal in a festive atmosphere.

events.title: March 20: Independence Day (national)
events.description: Commemorates Tunisia's independence from France, gained on this day in 1956, under the leadership of President Habib Bourguiba. Anniversary ceremonies emphasize national unity and celebrations across town include concerts, fireworks and traditional meals shared by families and friends.

events.title: Ninth month of the Hijri calendar: Ramadan (national)
events.description: The holy month of Ramadan, during which the Quran was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, is an especially pious time in Tunisia, a country with a majority Muslim population. Fasting begins each day at sunrise and ends at sunset. For the entire month, Tunis operates at a slower pace during the day and stirs into action at nightfall.

events.title: First two days of the tenth month of the Hijri calendar: Eid al-Fitr (national)
events.description: This two-day festival marks the end of Ramadan as well as the end of fasting, and is a time for family celebrations across Tunis, with exchanges of gifts, especially new clothes, and great feasts bringing together all family members. Music, dancing and street processions are also a prominent feature.

events.title: July 25: Republic Day (national)
events.description: Commemorates the proclamation on this day on July 25<sup>th</sup>, 1957 following a vote by the Constituent Assembly, which abolished the monarchy and established Tunisia as a republic. Anniversary celebrations include official ceremonies, parades and fireworks.

events.title: Tenth day of the last month of the Hijri calendar: Eid al-Adha (national)
events.description: This festival celebrated on the tenth day of Dhu al-Hijja honours Ibrahim's proof of his obedience to Allah. Allah asked him to sacrifice his son Ismael, but just as Ibrahim was about to make the sacrifice, Allah told him to offer a ram instead. Traditionally, to remember Ibrahim's offering, each family sacrifices a sheep in the morning and the remainder of the day is spent in prayer and celebration, feasting on the roast mutton and sharing the meat with others.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Tunisia
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Tunisia for less than three months. However, you must be in possession of a valid passport.

If you hold dual Tunisian and French citizenship, you will also need to present your valid Tunisian passport upon arrival.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Tunis and Tunisia, be sure to check the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website:
www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays/tunisie

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m., Saturday morning from 7:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. In July and August, administrations open only in the morning, from 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Thursday from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m., Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. and 1:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. In July and August, banks open only in the morning, from 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: There is no daylight savings in Tunisia.
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping

In Tunis and throughout Tunisia, tipping is not necessarily required, although always appreciated if you are satisfied with the service. There are no hard-and-fast rules for the amount to leave.
